text:
<@U4H19D1D2> possibly, but I'm aiming for 10+ sports and would need different filters for each sport. I'd probably be better off making this a polling bot and calling markets list and caching the IDs I want to keep. My CPU is already at 80% with 10 second conflated streaming and I've only added 2 sports. :rolling_on_the_floor_laughing: 
Can now see the limitations of streaming vs polling, which presumably is why Betfair still have both available.

text: come monday that CPU should be much lower as I am going to refactor the order execution logic, out of interest what version of bflw are you using?

elements.text: come monday that CPU should be much lower as I am going to refactor the order execution logic, out of interest what version of bflw are you using?

text: It's possible to process a lot of markets, but you have to be super-efficient and do very little in the main processing thread. I'm not sure how Flumine is architected, but I tend to allocate pre-processing of the stream to other threads

elements.text: It's possible to process a lot of markets, but you have to be super-efficient and do very little in the main processing thread. I'm not sure how Flumine is architected, but I tend to allocate pre-processing of the stream to other threads

text: so resource creation/processing is, the problem is that on every update the main thread checks every market to see if there are orders to process, this is fine when you have <250 markets but the problem becomes O(n2)

elements.text: so resource creation/processing is, the problem is that on every update the main thread checks every market to see if there are orders to process, this is fine when you have <250 markets but the problem becomes O(n2)

text: To cope with a very large number of markets (I can handle over 10,000) I don't check markets where I have not had a price update for a period of time

elements.text: To cope with a very large number of markets (I can handle over 10,000) I don't check markets where I have not had a price update for a period of time

text: (or in my case a score update, or any other update associated with that market)

elements.text: (or in my case a score update, or any other update associated with that market)

text: the problem is that it was designed to group orders together into a single request where possible, this is fine for my use case/strategies but not great if you want to process a lot of markets

elements.text: the problem is that it was designed to group orders together into a single request where possible, this is fine for my use case/strategies but not great if you want to process a lot of markets

text: Yep - the limitations of trying to have a generic design :wink:

elements.text: Yep - the limitations of trying to have a generic design

text: ha yep

elements.text: ha yep

text: but the change will make backtesting quicker so it needs to be done

text: In reality, I group markets for an "event" together so I have access to the other markets for the same event when checking

elements.text: In reality, I group markets for an "event" together so I have access to the other markets for the same event when checking

text: I have a "contest" which then has a number of "markets"

elements.text: I have a "contest" which then has a number of "markets"

text: The assumption is that a decision to bet could be across different markets for the same event, so they can all be accessed from one market

elements.text: The assumption is that a decision to bet could be across different markets for the same event, so they can all be accessed from one market

text: A contest has many markets, and when I check a market I have access to the contest, which has markets as its "children"

elements.text: A contest has many markets, and when I check a market I have access to the contest, which has markets as its "children"

text: This makes sense for tennis where the match can have a number of associated (and linked) markets

elements.text: This makes sense for tennis where the match can have a number of associated (and linked) markets

text: At the moment I am only looking at the match market, but eventually I want to be able to check them all

elements.text: At the moment I am only looking at the match market, but eventually I want to be able to check them all

text: What happens when you want make an order request? New thread per request?

text: My usage for this particular strategy is to have a small number of bets in lots of markets preplay, where speed is not required. Slow and steady wins this particular race, so polling is probably better suited. It's a shame that `listMarketCatalogue` doesn't have a param like `notMarketIds` where we could specify a list of market IDs that we're no longer interested in.

elements.text: My usage for this particular strategy is to have a small number of bets in lots of markets preplay, where speed is not required. Slow and steady wins this particular race, so polling is probably better suited. It's a shame that
listMarketCatalogue
doesn't have a param like
notMarketIds
where we could specify a list of market IDs that we're no longer interested in.

text: For mass-market trading I found that a multi-process setup was better. I.e. have N streamlisteners which recv mkdata from BF and publish it internally. For each market, start a process which subscribes to the relevant market data and submits any order actions to a process which does order management (sends new order/cancels to Betfair). OS scheduling for these processes is more than sufficient, and minimal CPU time is really wasted on markets you don't care about

elements.text: For mass-market trading I found that a multi-process setup was better. I.e. have N streamlisteners which recv mkdata from BF and publish it internally. For each market, start a process which subscribes to the relevant market data and submits any order actions to a process which does order management (sends new order/cancels to Betfair). OS scheduling for these processes is more than sufficient, and minimal CPU time is really wasted on markets you don't care about

text: Plus you can easily start a "logging" process which subscribes to the same internally broadcasted market data and logs it. All via zmq, the bottleneck is still mainly network connection to BF

elements.text: Plus you can easily start a "logging" process which subscribes to the same internally broadcasted market data and logs it. All via zmq, the bottleneck is still mainly network connection to BF

`{"asctime": "2021-01-30 08:31:23,529", "levelname": "WARNING", "message": "High latency between current time and MarketBook publish time", "market_id": "1.178427846", "latency": 752.4693222045898, "pt": "2021-01-30T08:18:50.921000"}`

`streaming_market_filter(event_type_ids=['1'])`
